description:
Plasmodium sp. gorilla clade G2 is a species of malaria parasite that infects gorillas (Gorilla spp.). It belongs to the Plasmodium genus, which is a group of unicellular eukaryotic organisms that are the causative agents of malaria in various vertebrate hosts, including humans, non-human primates, and other mammals.

The "gorilla clade G2" designation indicates that this particular Plasmodium species is genetically and phylogenetically distinct from other Plasmodium species found in gorillas, and it represents a separate evolutionary lineage within the broader Plasmodium parasite clade that infects gorillas.

Plasmodium sp. gorilla clade G2 is believed to have a life cycle and transmission dynamics similar to other Plasmodium species, involving an alternation between a mosquito vector (typically Anopheles mosquitoes) and a vertebrate host (in this case, gorillas). The parasite undergoes a complex developmental process within both the mosquito and the gorilla, involving asexual and sexual reproduction stages.

While the specific biological and epidemiological characteristics of Plasmodium sp. gorilla clade G2 are still an area of ongoing research, this species is of interest to scientists studying the evolution and diversity of malaria parasites, as well as the host-parasite interactions and potential zoonotic implications of Plasmodium infections in non-human primates.
